perturbation.explanation: The original contract provides a 30-day return window. Shortening the return window to 10 days contradicts consumer protection laws in many states (including California, where the contract is governed) that provide consumers with more extensive rights to return goods, especially software, for a refund. Many states require a minimum of 30 days for software returns.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Consumer Rights Act, implied warranty laws.

perturbation.original_text: Limited Warranty Cisco warrants that commencing from the date of shipment to Customer (but in case of resale by an authorized Cisco reseller, commencing not more than ninety (90) days after original shipment by Cisco), and continuing for a period of the longer of (a) ninety (90) days or (b) the software warranty period (if any) set forth in the warranty card accompanying the Product (if any): (a) the media on which the Software is furnished will be free of defects in materials and workmanship under normal use; and (b) the Software substantially conforms to its published specifications.
perturbation.changed_text: Limited Warranty Cisco warrants that commencing from the date of shipment to Customer (but in case of resale by an authorized Cisco reseller, commencing not more than thirty (30) days after original shipment by Cisco), and continuing for a period of the longer of (a) thirty (30) days or (b) the software warranty period (if any) set forth in the warranty card accompanying the Product (if any): (a) the media on which the Software is furnished will be free of defects in materials and workmanship under normal use; and (b) the Software substantially conforms to its published specifications.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the warranty period from 90 days to 30 days creates a legal contradiction. Many states have implied warranty laws that may require a more extended warranty period, especially for software. A shorter warranty period may be deemed unconscionable and unenforceable, particularly if the software is complex or critical to business operations. The implied warranty of merchantability under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) usually extends beyond 30 days.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), implied warranty of merchantability, California implied warranty laws.

perturbation.original_text: Customer Records. Customer grants to Cisco and its independent accountants the right to examine Customer's books, records and accounts during Customer's normal business hours to verify compliance with this Agreement. In the event such audit discloses non-compliance with this Agreement, Customer shall promptly pay to Cisco the appropriate license fees.
perturbation.changed_text: Customer Records. Customer grants to Cisco and its independent accountants the right to examine Customer's books, records and accounts to verify compliance with this Agreement. Such examination can occur at any time, with or without prior notice. In the event such audit discloses non-compliance with this Agreement, Customer shall promptly pay to Cisco the appropriate license fees.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the 'during Customer's normal business hours' limitation and adding 'at any time, with or without prior notice' creates a legal contradiction. Laws regarding privacy and reasonable business practices generally require some level of notice and respect for a business's operational hours. Unannounced, unrestricted access to a customer's financial records could be seen as an unreasonable intrusion and a violation of privacy laws and fair business practice regulations. This is especially true in California, where privacy rights are strongly protected.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California privacy laws, laws regarding fair business practices, implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.
